text: There is consolidation along the bronchial area in the left lingual segment. Internally accompanied by bronchiectasis and pleural invagination around the consolidation. There is no contradiction with the lung cancer you observed.

An irregular mass lesion of approximately 28 mm is seen, with the main part centred on the outside of the left lung lingular segment S4. The interior is occupied by infiltration shadows and ground-glass shadowing, and an expanded image partly remains in the bronchioles. Suspect minimally invasive adenocarcinoma with a predominant lepidic growth pattern.There is also a linear shadow on the margin that connects to the pleura, but we suspect the presence of inflammatory scars and fibrous changes.Based on impression, pleural infiltration is not suspected. Surgical treatment seems possible.

text: The M factor is considered to be M1c.

A lobular mass lesion with a major axis of 7.8 cm and a well-defined margin is seen centering on the S9/10 region of the lower lobe of the left lung. The inside is solid, but some air is present, and it appears to be a cavitary lesion. Ground-glass shadows can also be seen around it. Primary lung cancer is suspected. Multiple nodular shadows and mass shadows can be seen on the central side of the lesion. They are distributed along the bronchial vascular bundles in the lower lobe of the left lung, with lymphatic infiltration. The lesion invades the mediastinum from the left hilum. Metastasis to the left hilar and mediastinal lymph nodes are seen.

lower lobe of the left lung

We suspect these to be lung metastases.

A tumour with a diameter of 28 mm and a pleural indentation is seen in the upper right lobe S3. An air bronchogram is inside, and the border has a ground-glass shadow. It seems to be a lesion corresponding to a part-solid GGN. Lepidic predominant adenocarcinoma (LPA) is suspected. It seems to be equivalent to T1c in T classification.

The lower right lobe S6 also has a nodule with a small interlobar pleural indentation. Lung cancer cannot be ruled out here either, but it is difficult to distinguish it from inflammatory nodules. Please take a biopsy or monitor closely. No other lesions suspected to be accessory tumour nodules can be seen in the lung field.
